title.native: 機動警察パトレイバー 劇場版

description:
The year is 1999 and Tokyo's Mobile Police have a new weapon in the war on crime – advanced robots called Labors are used to combat criminals who would use the new technology for illegal means. The suicide of a mysterious man on the massive Babylon Project construction site sets off a cascade of events that may signal the destruction of Tokyo.

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.name: Cyberpunk
tags.description: Set in a future of advanced technological and scientific achievements that have resulted in social disorder.

tags.name: Noir
tags.description: Stylized as a cynical crime drama with low-key visuals.

tags.name: Police
tags.description: Centers around the life and activities of law enforcement officers.

tags.name: Real Robot
tags.description: Prominently features mechanical designs loosely influenced by real-world robotics.

tags.name: Terrorism
tags.description: Centers around the activities of a terrorist or terrorist organization.

tags.name: Detective
tags.description: Features a character who investigates and solves crimes.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Software Development
tags.description: Centers around characters developing or programming a piece of technology, software, gaming, etc.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Cosmic Horror
tags.description: A type of horror that emphasizes human insignificance in the grand scope of cosmic reality; fearing the unknown and being powerless to fight it.

node.description:
Headgear is a collective of creators established so all the involved could retain full copyright to their work, achieve greater publicity for their work and sell their manga to anime sponsors for film production.

Best known as the creators of the [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/1288/) series.

**Members:**

- [Masami Yuuki](https://anilist.co/staff/97011/) 
- [Yutaka Izubuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/99075/)
- [Akemi Takada](https://anilist.co/staff/100559/)
- [Kazunori Itou](https://anilist.co/staff/97941/) 
- [Mamoru Oshii](https://anilist.co/staff/99097/)

__Graduated:__ Toyo University

During school Sawai always aimed to be manga artist. After graduating from Toyo University he joined Tatsunoko Production where he became a storyboard artist and later episode director. He served two more years as a production assistant there until he left and became a freelance episode director. Today he works mainly for Bee Train, whose founder Kouichi Mashimo is a good friend of his.

[Website](http://takada-akemi.net/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/AngelTouchPlus)

Akemi Takada is a Japanese artist and illustrator, and was born on March 31 in Tokyo, Japan. She is a popular anime character designer who attended Tama Art University, and then worked for Tatsunoko Pro following her graduation. She is currently a freelance illustrator with her own studio, though she is also a member of the creative group Headgear. She also has her own designer jewelry store called Diakosmos.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/ogura_koubou)

In 1977, Ogura joined *Kobayashi Production* and learned the ropes of art direction under [Shichirou Kobayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/103964/Shichirou-Kobayashi). In 1983 he left and established Studio Fuga together with Kouji Oono and [Toshiharu Mizutani](https://anilist.co/staff/121908/Toshiharu-Mizutani). There he eventually left as well and formed his own 'Ogura Kobo' at Production I.G., where he trains newer art directors. He continues to be a major presence at Production I.G. as one of their most prominent art directors.

Ogura's style is, similar to Kobayashi's, rooted in imposing architecture, ambient colors, and Western perspectives versus traditional Japanese isometric perspectives. Ogura's backgrounds are usually urban in setting and has a less saturated color palette, and uses more cool than warm colors. Ogura's fantastical, European Kobayashi influence is easily seen in [Wings of Honneamise](https://anilist.co/anime/1034/Ouritsu-Uchuugun-Honneamise-no-Tsubasa/), and his later work has remained distinctly metropolitan, something that can be seen even in the rural [FLCL](https://anilist.co/anime/227/FLCL/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1522114648098619397)

He grew up admiring anime such as [Space Battleship Yamato](https://anilist.co/anime/1650/) an during highschool he started animating with his friends. He enrolled into a professional animation school after graduating but quit quickly due to being disappointed in how the lessons were conducted.

He joined Anime R and later its subsidiary Studio Muu. His first work was as an in-betweener on [Psycho Armor Govarian](https://anilist.co/anime/6428/) while his debut as a key animator was on [Captain Tsubasa](https://anilist.co/anime/2116/).

After working on [Mamoru Oshii](https://anilist.co/staff/99097/)'s [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/1095/) he permanently joined Production I.G. becoming known, together with [Hiroyuki Okiura](https://anilist.co/staff/103502/) and [Tetsuya Nishio](https://anilist.co/staff/103725/), as "The Three Gods of I.G."

He's is one of the most prominent animators of the realist school, with emphasis on solid shapes and weighty character animation.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/後藤隆幸)

Co-founder and representative director of [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/). The studio is named after him and [Mitsuhisa Ishikawa](https://anilist.co/staff/103267/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/斯波重治) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shigeharu_Shiba)

An award winning sound director.

Retired in 1999.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/oshii_mamoru)

An anime and live-action director, mostly known for the former, whose seminal titles include [Urusei Yatsura 2: Beautiful Dreamer](https://anilist.co/anime/1921/), [Angel's Egg](https://anilist.co/anime/885/), the first two [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/1095/) films and the [Ghost in the Shell](https://anilist.co/anime/43/) films, as well as the Kerberos Saga universe of which [Jin-Roh](https://anilist.co/anime/570/) is a part.

His affinity for Euro arthouse cinema, his falling out with the Christian religion, and his fascination with the unsuccessful anti-occupation, pro-communist protest movement in postwar Japan shaped his unusual sensibilities. Recurring themes and aesthetics in his works include oppressive police states, unsuccessful protest movements, dysfunctional bureaucracies, political action that results in stasis, biblical scripture, and imagery, philosophical dilemmas, characters trapped in seemingly inescapable situations, the use of dialog as descriptive "texture" rather than a plot-driver, and otherwise Euro-arthouse pacing and storyboarding. He is both polarizing to mainstream audiences, and highly revered by cinephiles and Hollywood directors; his works have influenced Hollywood films such as Dark City, The Matrix, and Avatar.

[Kenji Kamiyama](https://anilist.co/staff/100348/), an anime director also closely associated with [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/), is his protégé.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1522114648098619397)

He grew up admiring anime such as [Space Battleship Yamato](https://anilist.co/anime/1650/) an during highschool he started animating with his friends. He enrolled into a professional animation school after graduating but quit quickly due to being disappointed in how the lessons were conducted.

He joined Anime R and later its subsidiary Studio Muu. His first work was as an in-betweener on [Psycho Armor Govarian](https://anilist.co/anime/6428/) while his debut as a key animator was on [Captain Tsubasa](https://anilist.co/anime/2116/).

After working on [Mamoru Oshii](https://anilist.co/staff/99097/)'s [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/1095/) he permanently joined Production I.G. becoming known, together with [Hiroyuki Okiura](https://anilist.co/staff/103502/) and [Tetsuya Nishio](https://anilist.co/staff/103725/), as "The Three Gods of I.G."

He's is one of the most prominent animators of the realist school, with emphasis on solid shapes and weighty character animation.

A notable mechanical and character designer for both anime and tokusatsu series.

He aspired a career in the industry after having seen [Space Battleship Yamato](https://anilist.co/anime/1650/), a franchise in which he would eventually serve as a director [in 2012](https://anilist.co/anime/12029/). His career began in 1978, debuting as a mechanical designer on [Toushou Daimos](https://anilist.co/anime/2816/), designing the enemy robots. Few years later in 1981, he made his tokusatsu debut on Robot 8-chan.

The following decade he worked on industry shaping series such as [Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/86/), [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1089/) and [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/324/). During this time he also had ties to Parallel Creation, a creative group led by sci-fi writer [Aritsune Toyota](https://anilist.co/staff/220367/). This led him to work as an illustrator on novels such as [Record of Lodoss War](https://anilist.co/manga/92655/), in which his designs were deeply influential for Japanese fantasy series.

In 2002, he directed [RahXephon](https://anilist.co/anime/165/), an anime original created by him. Izubuchi said that his attempt was to set a new standard for mecha anime, as well as to bring back aspects of '70s mecha shows like [Brave Raideen](https://anilist.co/anime/2128/).

A trademark in his mechanical designs is the Buchi-hole (ブチ穴), a series of round holes embedded, usually in a cluster pattern of three holes above and two below, located somewhere on the mecha.

Headgear is a collective of creators established so all the involved could retain full copyright to their work, achieve greater publicity for their work and sell their manga to anime sponsors for film production.

Best known as the creators of the [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/1288/) series.

**Members:**

- [Masami Yuuki](https://anilist.co/staff/97011/) 
- [Yutaka Izubuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/99075/)
- [Akemi Takada](https://anilist.co/staff/100559/)
- [Kazunori Itou](https://anilist.co/staff/97941/) 
- [Mamoru Oshii](https://anilist.co/staff/99097/)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/竹内敦志)

Affiliated with [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/). Takeuchi is a renown mechanical designer and anime director, having worked on such high profile projects as [The Sky Crawlers](https://anilist.co/anime/3089/) and [Ghost in the Shell](Ghost in the Shell).

He also took part in the production of Star Wars: The Clone Wars.

Prodigious animator who entered the industry at the age of 16. Studied under [Moriyasu Taniguchi](https://anilist.co/staff/106638/).

Among the most technically adept of the realist movement, Okiura’s animation pushes photorealism to the limit. His scenes being so lifelike that they’re often confused for rotoscoping. He draws characters with realistic proportions and weighty movement, and is a perfectionist in the minor details. He’s particularly skilled with busy crowd shots.

Married to voice actress [Sumi Mutou](https://anilist.co/staff/96118/).
